metadata.case_name: Cis-Sutlej Jagirdars v. State of Punjab
metadata.case_number: Writ Petitions Nos. 82 of 1960, 148, 168-174, 357-361 of 1961; Civil Appeals Nos. 453-474 of 1961; Civil Appeal No. 50 of 1962

facts.text: In 1763, Sikh Chiefs crossed the Sutlej, overwhelmed Afghan Governor Zain Khan, occupied territory up to Jumna, and each declared himself ruler of occupied territory.
State of affairs continued until 1806 when Ranjit Singh built powerful State across Sutlej and occupied some Cis-Sutlej territories.

In 1809, British entered treaty with Ranjit Singh; he surrendered Cis-Sutlej acquisitions; Colonel Ochterlony proclaimed Cis-Sutlej Chiefs as sole owners, exempt from tribute, but required to furnish supplies and assist British; rule of lapse on death without issue.

In 1845-1846, war between British and Sikhs; Cis-Sutlej rulers neutral or hostile; British abolished police jurisdiction, transit/customs duties, accepted commutation for personal service (Governor General despatch November 7, 1846).
Second Sikh War ended in Punjab annexation; in June 1849, British declared Chiefs cease sovereign powers, lose jurisdictions, become ordinary subjects with exceptional privileges.
In 1852, British took over collection of revenue for jagir lands, made settlement rules, collected revenue, paid share to jagirdars.
Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1957 (Act 39 of 1957) came into force November 14, 1957; State proceeded to resume jagirs.

Writ petitions filed in Punjab High Court under Art. 226 challenging Act's validity and applicability; High Court by judgment May 25, 1959 upheld Act and applicability; granted leave to appeal under Art. 133(1)(a) January 27, 1960.
Petitions under Art. 32 filed in Supreme Court; civil appeals to Supreme Court.
Jagirs consist of right to revenue payable on lands, not estate in land under s.2(1)(b).
Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Amendment Act, 1959 inserted definition of State Government in s.2(5)(a) with retrospective effect from November 14, 1957.
Jagirdars accepted rules of descent under Punjab Jagirs Act, 1911 s.7(1)(b) by written instrument.

legal_issues.text: Whether Cis-Sutlej jagirs fall within definition of 'jagir' under s.2(1) of Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1957, particularly s.2(1)(a) as assignment of land revenue made by or on behalf of State Government.
Whether any assignment of land revenue was made to Cis-Sutlej jagirdars, and if so, by State Government as defined in s.2(5).
Validity of amendment to s.2(5) by Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Amendment Act, 1959.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cis-Sutlej jagirs not jagirs as no grant of jagirs or assignment of land revenue at any time; originally independent States held by sovereign rulers; British paid revenue to them as sovereigns, not as assignees.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(1)(a) Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1957

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if grant implied, not made by or on behalf of State Government as required by s.2(1)(a); British Government not State Government.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(1)(a), s.2(5) Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1957

petitioner_arguments.text: Amendment Act 1959 colourable legislation, beyond competence, converts Central into State Government, fraud on Constitution.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: List II Entries 18, 45 Seventh Schedule; Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: Cis-Sutlej jagirs within s.2(1)(a); implied assignment of land revenue by British Government, who reduced Chiefs to subjects; subsequent legislation treats as jagirs.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(1)(a), s.2(5); Punjab Land Revenue Act 1871; Punjab Descent of Jagirs Act 1900; Punjab Jagirs Act 1911

respondent_arguments.text: Amendment to s.2(5) intra vires, clarifies State Government includes predecessors like British.

court_reasoning.text: Cis-Sutlej Chiefs originally rulers by conquest in 1763; British established suzerainty 1809, deprived powers progressively 1846-1849, reducing to subjects; 1852 revenue settlement implies grant as subjects, not sovereigns.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Status either sovereign or subject, no intermediate; Chiefs subjects by 1849, revenue payment implies grant.

court_reasoning.text: Analogy to Thakur Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan: implied grant where rulers reduced to subjects; no conquest needed for sovereignty acquisition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grants may be implied; British exercised sovereign powers post-1849.

court_reasoning.text: 1846 proposal for resumption/re-grant rejected for policy reasons, not recognizing sovereignty; supports implied grant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mediatized rulers ceased to be rulers by 1849; revenue assignee per Baden Powell and Kensington.

court_reasoning.text: Subsequent laws (Land Revenue Act 1871, Descent Act 1900, Jagirs Act 1911) treat as subjects/jagirdars; acceptance of rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Irresistible conclusion of implied grants by British.

court_reasoning.text: s.2(5)(a) includes British as predecessor Government; amendment retrospective, intra vires under Entries 18,45 List II.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature competent to resume jagirs regardless of grantor.

holdings.text: Cis-Sutlej jagirs fall within s.2(1)(a) as implied assignment of land revenue by State Government (including British predecessors per s.2(5)).
Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Amendment Act, 1959 valid and intra vires.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thakur Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Implied grant to former rulers reduced to subjects; no tertium quid between sovereign and subject.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cook v. Sir James Gordon Sprigg
precedents_cited.relevance: Sovereignty acquisition not limited to conquest; includes cession or other means.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Act of State includes acquisition by conquest, cession, occupation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalmia Dadri Cement Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Act of State includes all first-time territory acquisitions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Promod Chandra Deb v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Act of State is taking sovereign powers over new territory by conquest, treaty, cession or otherwise.
Apportionment of compensation under Land Acquisition Act; not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Orissa v. Madan Gopal Rungta
precedents_cited.relevance: No directions on payment pending appeal without deciding rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Ghafoor Khan v. Amarjit Singh
precedents_cited.citation: Regular Second Appeal No. 561 of 1946 (Punjab HC)
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on no gift/assignment obiter; not on land revenue.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines jagir, jagirdar, State Government; extinguishes jagirs on commencement.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Resumption of Jagirs (Amendment) Act, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrospective insertion of s.2(5)(a) defining State Government to include predecessors like British.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petitions and appeals.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1871
statutes_cited.relevance: Settlement and collection of land revenue; British exercised sovereign fiscal jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Descent of Jagirs Act, 1900
statutes_cited.relevance: Rules of descent for jagirs; recognition by Provincial Government.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Jagirs Act, 1911
statutes_cited.relevance: Consolidates law on assignments of land revenue known as jagirs; jagirdars accepted rules.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds Punjab High Court judgment; holds Cis-Sutlej jagirs within Act's definition, Act and amendment valid; dismisses writ petitions and civil appeals; no directions on intervener's compensation claims as outside scope.

key_quotes.text: The status of a person must be either that of a sovereign or a subject. There is no tertium quid.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects intermediate status; basis for implied grant to subjects.

key_quotes.text: A grant may be implied as well as express.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Thakur Amar Singhji; applies to Cis-Sutlej jagirdars.

key_quotes.text: Under our Settlement arrangements, the jagirdar does not receive the revenue... He in fact is a mere assignee of the revenue.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Baden Powell; confirms assignee status.
